title: Data to Support Hypothesis Arctic Warming

content.question: Based on the data above, which of the following best supports the hypothesis that the Arctic (latitudes greater than <math alttext="66 degrees north " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>66</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>N</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) experienced accelerated warming compared to the rest of the planet from 2011 to 2017 ?

choices.label: The smallest average surface-temperature change occurred at about <math alttext="negative 80 degrees " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>80</mn><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math> latitude in the Antarctic.

The largest areas with surface-temperature changes greater than a <math alttext="4 degrees Celsius " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> increase are found in the Arctic.
Northern Australia warmed more than the ocean off the west coast of Australia did.

The average surface-temperature change at the equator was about a <math alttext="0.6 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.6</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> increase.

content.answer: The largest areas with surface-temperature changes greater than a <math alttext="4 degrees Celsius " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> increase are found in the Arctic.

skill.text: Skill 5.D: Interpret experimental data and results in relation to a given hypothesis.
